Comment: Another Muzio gambit. This time around, the game did not go as planned as my opponent put on a dogged defence. I had to rely on setting up a trap and inviting a blunder to win. I would appreciate any comments as to where I went wrong in my development that allowed Black a remarkable fight.
the first 4 moves a set by the tournament opening
The idea being offering up a whole knight for a pawn for a significant lead in developement
There goes the pawn
protecting against a queen raid with check
Black tries to hang on to this won pawn and seek to advance to attack the knight
White is preparing for an attack on the f7 pawn. In this opening, if Black accepts the gambit, he must also accept that he won't be able to castle

The attack on the knight. The following move is the first free one in the tournament. I am not inclined to a loose the right to castle. I could take my knight to e5 and initiate a second attack on f7 but then Black would respond with 5...Qh4+ 6. Kf1 with a ready made attack with pawns and a queen to try and opening up my king's position. I must admit I do not like the games that emerge from this variation as the board becomes extremely complex.  For these reasons, I allow Black to take up the knight
I castle, allowing Black a free knight for a pawn

Question: Do is it better to take the pawn with the rook, allowing a line up rook/queen later or with the queen for a queen/rook? The first one seems to be more sensible given that the rook is less valuable, at the same time, there is nothing better than a check with a queen which argues for a queen first. Any thoughts?
I choose to take the pawn with my queen
Black tries to protect the pawn. I think 6...Qf6 is a better move for black as it threatens a fork with check on the White bishop on c4 with 7...Qd4+
Playing up the bishop first, allows White to double move the d pawn for a firm grip of the sweet centre and an attack on Black's f4 pawn
A move late but there comes the threat of the fork with check that I must address in my next move
I shore up the d pawn. So far, So good? Thoughts?
White liberates his bishop. Very good play I thought. My bishop on c4 will come under pressure at some point

Instead of 9.Bxf4, which would have set in motion a series of capture/re-capture which would reduce my deficit to -2, I decide to continue developing hoping it would pay off later. Plus my next (or few) move would liberate my second rook. Or so I thought
Black is now a just a couple of steps behind in development. White starts to panick... The gambit is about to fall flat. Any thoughts?
I take the f4 pawn at last
re-capture
